questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

Evaluates practical multi-tenant security controls, policy-as-code, and operational testing in Kubernetes.

## Key Concepts

- Admission control with Gatekeeper or Kyverno
- Namespace RBAC scoping
- Calico NetworkPolicy isolation
- Auditing and runbooks
- CI validation and drift checks

## Code Example

```javascript
apiVersion: constraints.gatekeeper.sh/v1beta1
kind: K8sNSApproved
metadata:
  name: ns-approved
spec:
  match:
    namespaces: ["approved-*"]
```

```javascript
apiVersion: kyverno.io/v1
kind: ClusterPolicy
metadata:
  name: restrict-privileges
spec:
  rules:
  - name: disallow-privileged
    match:
      resources:
        kinds: ["Pod"]
    validate:
      message: "Privileged containers are not allowed"
      pattern:
        spec:
          containers:
          - securityContext:
              allowPrivilegeEscalation: false
              readOnlyRootFilesystem: true
```

```javascript
apiVersion: networking.k8s.io/v1
kind: NetworkPolicy
metadata:
  name: deny-all
spec:
  podSelector: {}
  policyTypes: ["Ingress","Egress"]
  ingress: []
  egress: []
```

## Follow-up Questions

- How would you test these policies in CI?
- How would you handle policy drift and remediation?

questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked
Tests end-to-end security for ML artifacts, combining signing attestations, GitOps, and runtime policy in Kubernetes.

- Sigstore Cosign sign-blob attest and verify-blob
- Model provenance and SBOM
- GitOps with Argo CD
- Admission policies: OPA Gatekeeper or Kyverno

## Code Example
```bash
# Sign a model blob and create an attestation
cosign sign-blob -key cosign.key models/model-v1.bin
cosign attest -key cosign.key --predicate predicate.json models/model-v1.bin
cosign verify-blob -key cosign.pub models/model-v1.bin
```

```yaml
# Kyverno policy requiring attestation before deployment
apiVersion: kyverno.io/v1
kind: ClusterPolicy
metadata:
  name: require-model-attestation
spec:
  validationFailureAction: enforce
  rules:
  - name: attested-model-artifact
    match:
      resources:
        kinds: [Deployment]
    validate:
      message: Attestation required for model artifact
      pattern:
        metadata.annotations.cosign_attested: "true"
```

```rego
package kubernetes.admission

deny[{"msg": msg}] {
  input.request.kind.kind == "Deployment"
  not input.request.object.metadata.annotations["cosign_attested"] == "true"
  msg = "Model artifact must be attested with cosign before deployment"
}
```

- How would you test end-to-end in CI/CD and cluster?

## Why This Is Asked
Tests cross-cloud supply chain security for serverless deployments, requiring practical steps to sign artifacts, publish attestations, and enforce those attestations across multiple cloud platforms.

- Sigstore cosign and SLSA attestations

## Code Example
```yaml
# GitHub Actions: sign and attest serverless image
name: Sign and Attest Serverless Images
on:
  push:
    branches: [ main ]
jobs:
  sign_attest:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      - name: Setup cosign
        uses: sigstore/cosign-installer@v1
      - name: Build image
        run: |
          IMAGE=registry.example.com/function-${{ github.sha }}:latest
          docker build -t $IMAGE .
      - name: Sign image
        run: cosign sign --key cosign.key $IMAGE
      - name: Attest image
        run: cosign attest --key cosign.key --predicate attest.json $IMAGE
```

```rego
# Kyverno policy enforcing attestations (example)
package sigstore

default allow = false

allow {
  input.attestations[_].predicate.type == "type.googleapis.com/slsa.Provenance"
  input.image.docker_content_digest != ""
}
```

questions.explanation:
## Why This Is Asked

This question evaluates practical understanding of Kubernetes security primitives including RBAC, ServiceAccount isolation, PodSecurityContext, and admission controls—essential skills for securing containerized workloads.

## Key Concepts

- **Namespace-scoped RBAC**: Role and RoleBinding for resource access control within specific namespaces
- **ServiceAccount isolation**: Dedicated service accounts to separate pod identities and permissions
- **PodSecurityContext**: Security constraints including runAsNonRoot, runAsUser, readOnlyRootFilesystem, and capability dropping
- **Admission controls**: PodSecurity standards and OPA Gatekeeper for policy enforcement at admission time

## Code Example

```yaml
# ServiceAccount (dev)
apiVersion: v1
kind: ServiceAccount
metadata:
  name: data-processor-sa
  namespace: dev
---
# Role for read-only access to ConfigMaps and Secrets
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: Role
metadata:
  name: data-processor-role
  namespace: dev
rules:
- apiGroups: [""]
  resources: ["configmaps", "secrets"]
  verbs: ["get", "list"]
---
# RoleBinding
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1
kind: RoleBinding
metadata:
  name: data-processor-binding
  namespace: dev
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: data-processor-sa
  namespace: dev
roleRef:
  kind: Role
  name: data-processor-role
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
```

- How would you test the RBAC permissions locally?
- What changes are needed for the prod namespace?
- How would you implement network policies alongside these security controls?

```yaml
apiVersion: kyverno.io/v1
kind: ClusterPolicy
metadata:
  name: require-attested-wasm
spec:
  rules:
  - name: attestation-check
    match:
      resources:
        kinds:
        - Pod
        selector:
          matchLabels:
            app: wasm-edge
    validate:
      pattern:
        spec:
          containers:
          - image: "ghcr.io/org/*"

                add: ["SYS_ADMIN"]

    match:
      resources:
        kinds:
        - Pod
    validate:
      anyPattern:
      - pattern:
          metadata:
            annotations:
              cosign.sigstore.dev/attestations: "?*"
```
